awd_titl_txt: Fifty Years of Number Theory and Random Matrix Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides partial support for attendees at "50 Years of Number Theory and Random Matrix Theory Conference," which will take place at the Institute for Advanced Study on June 21-24, 2022. This conference will bring together people from two different areas: Number Theory and Random Matrix theory to discuss the ideas that are relevant to both fields. In the last 50 years there has been a large body of compelling work that uses Random Matrix Theory and gets to the very heart of some of the most important problems in Number Theory. The conference will give a historical perspective but will also be very forward looking in its emphasis on contemporary research.  The award will support about 30 participants with an emphasis on supporting early career researchers as well as  members of under-represented groups. The talks will be streamed and recorded so that they can be available to a wide audience.


Mathematicians  realized 50 years ago that the zeros of the Riemann zeta-function are distributed like the eigenvalues of large random Hermitian matrices with normally distributed entries. That discovery set things in motion, which in the past 20 years have really taken off. Learning how to use Random Matrix Theory as a model and guide to understanding the interesting arithmetic statistics of families of L-functions is indispensable for today's researcher. This conference will highlight some of the past achievements but will concentrate on current work, such as Paul Nelson's groundbreaking work on subconvexity for L-functions attached to automorphic forms on GL(n), that is paving the way for future work.

The relevant website is https://www.ias.edu/math/events/50yntrmt

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
50 Years of Number Theory and Random Matrix Theory. 50 years ago there was a remarkable chance meeting in the tea room at the Institute for Advanced Study (IAS) in Princeton between Hugh Montgomery, a graduate student in mathematics, and Freeman Dyson, a famous physicist and permanent member of IAS. This meeting sparked a revolution and inspired work that is still going on today at the nexus of these two fields. The conference supported by this grant offered a chance for roughly 100 people to hear 14 plenary addresses about ongoing research in this area. 33 participants were supported by this grant, of whom 21 were graduate students or junior faculty and 8 were women. Five of the 14 plenary addresses were given by women.  There was plenty of time for interaction among the participants and speakers as there was morning coffee, lunches provided for everyone, evening happy hour and a dinner for all. In addition there was a problem session/open discussion about the future of the subject. Videos from all of the talks are available on the Institute for Advanced Study website and the notes from the problem session are available on the American Institute of Mathematics (AIM) website aimath.org.  The conference began with a 90 minute presentation by Hugh Montgomery, Jon Keating and Peter Sarnak which revisited the actual event being celebrated and history of the progress since, paying particular attention to singular events along the way. Then there were 14 plenary addresses on many aspects of today's  connections between Random Matrix Theory and Number Theory.  For researchers today the tools and insights afforded by Random Matrix Theory are indispensible for modeling the behavior of families of L-functions, which are among the main objects of study in NumberTheory. Two of the talks at the conference were exceptional in their far-reaching advances in the subject: Paul Nelson's talk about his work on subconvexity for high degree L-functions; and Sieg Baluyot's talk on moments of families of L-functions.  It is expected that this conference will inspire much future work in this important area.
